pullRequest.body:
Bug fixes
1. Fix infinite loop triggered by `(by fun_prop : ?m)`
2. Support for multiple lambda theorems. For example `ContinuousOn` has multiple versions of composition theorem.
3. Support for special constant lambda theorem. For example `IsLinearMap R fun _ => 0` should be registered as constant lambda theorem
4. Improved error messages when trying `fun_prop` on non-fun_prop goal
5. Improved error messages when missing lambda theorems

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]
-->

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

nodes.body:
One more fix for expressions involving `Expr.proj`

For example this was failing
```
example : Continuous fun ((x, y, z) : ‚Ñù √ó ‚Ñù √ó ‚Ñù) ‚Ü¶ y := by fun_prop
example : Continuous fun ((x, y, z) : ‚Ñù √ó ‚Ñù √ó ‚Ñù) ‚Ü¶ z := by fun_prop
```
Would you mind adding some more inline comments? The code would be easier to understand.
Do you have a specific part in mind? I can make it more readable. It would be difficult for me to do so without knowing what to improve.
@alexjbest if you wouldn't mind taking a look at this at some point I would greatly appreciate it!

I think I have addressed all the comments except for the `if then else`. I disagree that every `if` should be commented, the function there is literally called `tryTheorem...`, so the `if` statement is testing if trying a theorem succeed or not.

I have removed the `awaiting-review` label according to the decision explained here
https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/113486-announce/topic/Changes.20to.20the.20.23queue/near/450176907

> I'll stop my review here for now, mainly addressing the logging question. I'll look at the rest later.
> 
> Generally, it does help a lot if PRs containing several, mostly independent, changes are split into a few smaller PRs containing a single self-contained feature. Unfortunately, reviewing time grows faster than linear with the PR size.
> 
> Further, I already marked various styling issues (like double whitespace), but maybe you could just have another cleanup round yourself first.

Sorry about this. This PR was supposed to be just a fix to few bugs but then it got blocked because there was tons of missing docs. I got a bit frustrated by it as I didn't have the time to write it back then. As it is now bug fixes+doc PR I thought I can also squeeze update to logging.

Anyway, thanks a lot for picking on logging as I definitely left it half unfinished. I will clean it up now!

@joneugster Thanks you very much for a great review! Hopefully I have addressed all your comments.

I added a new option `maxTransitionDepth` and `transitionDepth` context variable which limits how many transition theorems can be used. This allowed for few simplification. Logging happens only with `transitionDepth=0` and `thrmStack` has been completely removed which was an incomplete solution to prevent loops anyway.
I think I have resolved all the remaining issues.
üöÄ Pull request has been placed on the maintainer queue by joneugster.

This makes it sound like you need to do this if you just register a `CoeFun` instance on some type, which I think is not true since coercions are unfolded in Lean 4. I believe this would only be an issue if you create a new *class* `MyFunLike` with a `toFun` field and for that class you defined a `CoeFun` instance. Then the coercion for *instances* of that class would unfold to have a head function of `MyFunLike.toFun` instead of their underlying definition.

Am I correct? Or have I misunderstood?
Yes you are right. I will add an example with `MyFunLike` that will prevent the confusion.
Can you provide an explanation of why this is necessary? At this point I have no understanding of why that's necessary or how that exception should be generalized to other contexts.

Because the theorem for `Prod.mk` is used to decompose more complicated functions into simpler. 

For example,
When you want to prove something about the function `(fun x => sin (exp x) + cos (exp x))` it get decomposed as
```
(fun x => x.1 + x.2)
‚àò
(fun x => (sin (exp x), cos (exp x)))
```
You should have exact theorem for `(fun x => x.1 + x.2)`. 

To deal with `fun x => (sin (exp x), cos (exp x))` you apply theorem for `Prod.mk` to decompose it into two problems, one for `fun x => sin (exp x)` and one for `fun x => cos (exp x)`.

I added 
> This because this theorem together with *lambda theorems* is used to break expression to smaller pieces and `fun_prop`  assumes it is written in compositional form.

Does that make it a bit more clear?
Is there a reason not to use the notation `-` here instead of `Neg.neg`? If there is, that's fine, but it's not clear to me at the moment.

I'm doing it because for example for `a + b` the head of this expression is `HAdd.hAdd`  which is obvious when you write it as `HAdd.hAdd a b` and you don't even know what is the definition of "head of an expression".

Maybe should I switch to some functions that don't have this issue? Maybe `sin` and what would be a good two argument function?

No, that's fine, it makes sense, but perhaps a short parenthetical comment to the effect of "(the *head* of an expression is the term which appears first in the tree; for binary operations, like `a + b`, after stripping away the syntactic sugar / notation this becomes `HAdd.hAdd a b`; here we prefer the latter to make the head expression more obvious)"
Hmmm... this seems to me like it will be a real problem in practice. We may need to at least have the option to roll back the state.
Yeah it will probably come up. I will think about it but will not solve it right now.

1. Should these have `(inherited := true)` so that `set_option trace.Meta.Tactic.fun_prop` enables all of them? (see [docstring of `registerTraceClass`](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Lean/Util/Trace.html#Lean.registerTraceClass))
2. These could benefit from docstrings explaining what sort of traces they enable.

What is the intended way to add doc to an option? 

Like this?
```
/-- bla bla bla -/
initialize registerTraceClass `Meta.Tactic.fun_prop
```

Also I will just cut the tracing options to
```
Meta.Tactic.fun_prop
Meta.Tactic.fun_prop.attr
Debug.Meta.Tactic.fun_prop
```
I don't think there is a need for more right now.

Thanks that makes it much more understandable!

Yes, if you add a docstring `/-- yada yada -/` to `initialize registerTraceClass` I think it appears on hover. However, this is completely optional for this PR!

This entire approach to logging seems a bit peculiar to me. I feel like the more common ways to do this would be either:

### Option A

Use just one `msgLog` as before and no "LoggingMode". Create an option

```
register_option Meta.Tactic.fun_prop.errors : Bool := {
  defValue := false
  descr := "yada yada" }
```

and then use `if Meta.Tactic.fun_prop.errors.get (‚Üê getOptions) then` whenever you want to add a "secondary" log message. (this approach does not sort them as main/secondary, but seems much simpler)

### Option B

Just use `trace[Meta.Tactic.fun_prop.errors]` wherever you have these secondary error messages, don't bother about the sorting and have the error say something like "enable `set_option trace.Meta.Tactic.fun_prop.errors true` to see more details!" No need for the "LoggingMode" either.

### Option C
If you really think adding `LoggingMode` adds value, I'd still suggest you use `register_option` instead of `registerTraceClass`.

In any case, it would be nice to have a test in the dev-test file using `#guard_msgs` which demonstrates the expected error message, would help understanding and reviewing..

The secondary errors are already reported with `set_option trace.Meta.Tactic.fun_prop` so I'm going to completely ditch the main/secondary dichotomy. 

I'm also going to include few tests with `#guard_msgs` to the dev file as you suggest.
Thanks!


```suggestion

```

```suggestion
Messages are logged only when `transitionDepth = 0` i.e. when `fun_prop` is **not** trying to infer
function property like continuity from another property like differentiability.
The main reason is that if the user forgets to add a continuity theorem for function `foo` then
`fun_prop` should report that there is a continuity theorem for `foo` missing. If we would log
messages `transitionDepth > 0` then user will see messages saying that there is a missing theorem for
differentiability, smoothness, ... for `foo`.  -/
```

```suggestion
abbrev FunPropM := ReaderT FunProp.Context <| StateT FunProp.State MetaM
```
See [Style guide](https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/style.html#whitespace-and-delimiters)

```suggestion
/-- Environment extension storing lambda theorems. -/
```

```suggestion
/-- Environment extension storing all lambda theorems. -/
```
why does this fail now?
This is because support for functions of the form `fun x => let y:= g x; f x y` is missing. Can be a new PR.

New tactic documentation.
Mainly split `FunProp.Context` into `Config` (settings set by the user) and `Context` (local storage of the tactic)
Main change is that the inductive types have been simplified, along with other simplifications.
This is mostly refactoring code, plus a small fix about dealing with `let`.
This has a series of clean-ups to all the `applyXXXRule` declarations.
